subject: Re: Jupiter is shrinking?
author: Adriana Jones
full_text:
Why is it that science can figure out that Jupiter.... JUPITER!.... a frazillion miles away is shrinking by 2 dinkymeters a year, but they can't put their heads together to solve world hunger, and other more pressing problems.... sorry, snow I don't want to take away from your post, I just had to get that off my chest....

--- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, SnowfireL@... wrote:
>
> Interesting things about Jupiter:  "Although Jupiter would need to be  
> about 75 times as massive to fuse hydrogen and become a _star_ 
> (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) , the smallest _red dwarf_ 
> (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_dwarf)  is only about 30  percent larger in radius than Jupiter._[27]_ 
> (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jupiter#cite_note-26) _[28]_ 
> (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jupiter#cite_note-27)   Despite this, Jupiter still radiates 
> more heat than it receives from the Sun.  The amount of heat produced inside 
> the planet is nearly equal to the total _solar radiation_ 
> (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_radiation)  it  receives._[29]_ 
> (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jupiter#cite_note-elkins-tanton-28)   This additional heat radiation is 
> generated by the _Kelvin-Helmholtz  mechanism_ 
> (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kelvin-Helmholtz_mechanism)  through _adiabatic_ 
> (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adiabatic_process)  contraction.  This process results in the planet 
> shrinking by about 2 cm each year._[30]_ 
> (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jupiter#cite_note-guillot04-29)   When it was first formed, Jupiter was much hotter 
> and was about twice its  current diameter._[31]_ 
> (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jupiter#cite_note-30) "
>
